channel.title: A Few Questions
channel.description:
Alright im working on a GUI i have been for a while now and i have a few questions.
[b]Q1 - How would i make the background of the GUI a picture. like clients on mscp. i've never even touched a client so i dont know if that would help me or not.
[s]Q2 - How do i add text feilds to the GUI[/s]
Q3 - How do i make the Menu Bar do a double drop screen (example-click file on the top of your window and i mean like New >)[/b]
thats all for now

item.title: A Few Questions
item.dc:creator: @pizza_pie pizza pie
item.description:
@pizza_pie wrote:

How about this:

Toolkit tool = Toolkit.getDefaultToolkit();
private Image bg = tool.getImage("./Background.gif");

----------------------------------------------------------

int height = -1, width = -1;
while(height == -1 || width == -1) {
       width = bg.getWidth(this);
       height = bg.getHeight(this);
}
setSize(width, height);
setResizable(false);
setVisible(true);

Now it’s the background, because the window will be the size of the picture and will not resizable…

Read full topic

item.title: A Few Questions
item.dc:creator: @Iamadam Iamadam
item.description:
@Iamadam wrote:

[quote=“Pwnd, post:8, topic:120780”]JMenuBar mb = new JMenuBar();
JMenu file = new JMenu(“File”);
JMenuItem exit = new JMenuItem(“Exit”);

file.add(exit);
mb.add(file);[/quote]
I don’t think that’s what he wanted. From what I understand, he wants to add a JMenu to another JMenu [File -> New -> Document]. I think.

JMenuBar mb = new JMenuBar(); JMenu file = new JMenu("File"); JMenu new = new JMenu("New"); JMenuItem doc = new JMenuItem("Document"); new.add(doc); file.add(new); mb.add(file);

Read full topic

item.title: A Few Questions
item.dc:creator: @ilyaostr9 io9
item.description:
@ilyaostr9 wrote:

You would either:

A) Make a custom JFrame ( which would be something along the lines of public class CustomJFrame extends JContainer)
or,
B) Make a Canvas, draw the background, and then add components to that Canvas, which would be something along the lines of:

Toolkit t = Toolkit.getDefaultToolkit();
BufferedImage ourBackground = new BufferedImage(t.createImage(t.getImage("IMAGE FILENAME HERE"))); // Cause we don't want our background to flicker ;)
Canvas c = new Canvas();
JFrame ourFrame = new JFrame("HAHA");
c.setSize(100, 100);
ourFrame.setSize(108 /* Canvas' x + 8*/, 128 /* Canvas' y + 28 */); // I added those because of borders and title bar
ourFrame.setResizable(false);
c.paint(ourBackground.createGraphics());
JButton lawl = new JButton("LAWL COOKIE FOR MEH!");
c.add(LAWL);

I obviously whipped that up right now, so I’m not sure if it’ll work or not.

[quote=“I Metal I, post:5, topic:120780”][quote author=Yz85Racer link=topic=170356.msg1578141#msg1578141 date=1183873368]

The answer to question 1 is:

The “backgrounds” on mscp clients is not a backgroudnd, but the result of drawing an image on the client’s canvas.

pwnt
[/quote]
Yz gtfo no one needs your input. your only acting this way towards me because you were banned from a forum that dosent even exist anymore. Grow Up[/quote]
In the words of a certain Kyle Richards, “pwnt”

Read full topic

item.title: A Few Questions
item.dc:creator: @_Java1 † Java †
item.description:
@_Java1 wrote:

to add textfields add this,

JTextField field1 = new JTextField(10);

then add it, 10 is the size of the field in width,

to add a menubar

JMenuBar jmb = new JMenuBar();

then add a menu to it, like file,

JMenu file = new JMenu("File);

then add something to drop down from file,

JMenuItem filedrop = new JMenuItem("Drop");

then add them all

JFrame.setMenuBar(jmb); // I think.. jmb.add(file); file.add(filedrop);

EDIT: Oh i see what you meant with the JMenu side out thingy, havent really gotten there

Read full topic
